If you can set up a new account for the outgoing server, do this for a new outgoing message setting Smtp.

choose to create a new account for this and sending your email s will work again in Thunderbird.

forcing a password

content: This is working fine with Windows. Please give more information, as your screenshot indicates you are successfully coloring the text.
creator: davidsk

content: You are not getting it. I can't show you what doesn't work. In the function in my screenshot, there is a place for custom colours (empty boxes at the bottom). You can set them up (fill the boxes) but they don't hold. The next time you open that function, the custom colours will be gone. The colour that are available (pre-set)of mostly too light for text and too dark for the difference in colour to show. Those pre-set colours were badly designed.
creator: quaternalmoon131

content: Then please clarify what you mean, as your duplicate thread shows a screenshot with text in color. Saying color does not hold doesn't explain whatever the issue is. Is this Windows, Linux, or a MAC?
creator: davidsk

content: I don't see how whether my computer is Windows, Linux, or Mac makes any difference. Yes -- thunderbird does have pre-set colours for text. Most of them are too light for text, or so dark that you can't tell the difference between colours. TB offers the ability to create custom colours. However, before the last update, TB would hold any custom colours one created - after the update, it will not hold them.
creator: quaternalmoon131

content: Could you post a screenshot of a message with some color, some darker colors and some text with lighter colors?
creator: davidsk

content: It really doesn't matter whether I think that the pre-set colours are too light or too dark. The point is that the custom colours do not hold.
creator: quaternalmoon131

content: Your screenshot shows that colors are working. If the sent message doesn't include the colors, it might be that you have Thunderbird set to send plain text only, or you may have an addon that is preventing colors in outgoing mail.
creator: davidsk

content: NO!!! You are not understanding. I am talking about the custom colours, NOT the pre-set ones. And I sent an email with the pre-set colours to show that they are not very readable, especially if the whole email has that version of the colour.
creator: quaternalmoon131

content:
Please look at the screenshot. You will see a lot of pre-set colours and then farther down a bunch of empty boxes. Those empty boxes are for the custom colours, and they are empty because Thunderbird doesn't hold/keep the custom colours anymore.

I am very surprised that many of the responsers to this problem have no idea what custom colours for text are.
creator: quaternalmoon131

content: FINALLY, I understand you. You're right, it's broken. I verified that it worked in 102. I submitted a bug report at https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1896960 Thank you for your patience in explaining it. Sometimes my brain does not connect.  :)
creator: davidsk

content: Thank-you, David for reporting the bug on this. I didn't know how to let TB know about this. I realize that it is not important to many TB users; but for those of us who regularly use the custom colours feature. Because the custom colours are not working any more, we have to change the shade/etc of the colour we want every single time that we change text colours. Blessings!
creator: quaternalmoon131

content: You are welcome. I regret it took me so long to figure it out.
creator: davidsk

content:
How did you install TB? If the icon isn't dragged to the Applications folder, the account setup details aren't retained between restarts.

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/installing-thunderbird-on-mac
creator: sfhowes

content: You do not nee allmail or important folders. In gmail, everything is one folder, but thunderbird has to create each as separate folders for consistency. Whatever is in the important and all mail folders is also in your inbox, sent, etc. and trash. That will save a lot of disk space and the need for thunderbird to update them. just highlight the account from main view, rightclick and select 'subscribe' and untick allmail and important
creator: davidsk

content: If you're comfortable working at the file level, you can still access it. - click help.troubleshootinginformation - scroll down to 'profile folder' and click 'open profile' - exit thunderbird - if the folder was in POP or local folders, click the Mail folder and then possibly the Local Folders folder and the renamed file should appear. Rename it back to what it was, delete the associated msf file, and then restart thunderbird and see if it appears.
creator: davidsk

content: Thanks for your reply! The issues got resolved. The renamed folders were hidden, what I did was clicked on my mail account and selected subscribe option where all my folders (including the renamed ones) were shown, there I selected the folders to be shown in inbox and saved, and they're visible in my inbox now.
creator: vivedha_r

content: You might start by reviewing the external media copy to see what is there. If there, then I would look at the profile on old computer to see if it's different. if the profile on old PC does not have the local folders-1, then I suggest redoing the copy.
creator: davidsk

content: Both the external media copy and the original profile on the old computer are identical in that they both have the local folders and local folders-1. The profile on the new computer contains the same folders, but Thunderbird will only look at the local folders-1 folder. The contents of these folders are all the same too.
creator: brianlec

content: You stated in original post that there were no folders in the -1 folder, but your second post indicates that the two folders contain the same contents. Have you tried clicking 'account settings', scrolling down to Local Folders and changing where it's pointing?
creator: davidsk

content: Thank you, I did manage to change the local folder to the one I need with your help.
creator: brianlec

content:
This is a tad out-of-date, but should give an overview. 

 http://kb.mozillazine.org/Files_and_folders_in_the_profile_-_Thunderbird
creator: davidsk

content: Yes. My suggestion, assuming you use standard setup: - exit tb on old pc - copy c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to external media - install tb on new pc and then exit - copy thunderbird folder from external media to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming which will overlay the default thunderbird folder created during the install - start tb
creator: davidsk

The settings need to be IMAP to synchronize.

content:
You list 125.0 (64 bit), which likely was incorrectly installed by some management software that you have running on your computer.

This is not a version that should be used. See https://thunderbird.topicbox.com/groups/planning/Ta13f7e0c19d8f0b9/tb-planning-monthly-releases-update-125-0-being-interpreted-as-production

You should install 115 from https://getthunderbird.com/
